description.narrative:
The Goal of the Capfish/FOSTER project is to improve the socio-economic conditions of the fishing communities and environmental sustainability of the (Western) Tonle Sap Biosphere Reserve (TSBR) through community-centered interventions reaching over 200000 women, men and children in Cambodia. The Capfish/FOSTER Project led by Oxfam and 14 partners has 3 Objectives: 1)Fishing communities in the Tonle Sap have increased access to safe water supply, hygiene and sanitation services2) Vulnerable and poor girls and boys are provided with increased availability and accessibility to education and can successfully transition through school 3) Fishing communities in the Tonle Sap have developed sustainable alternative livelihoods.
In order to respond to theurgent need for fishing communities to diversify their livelihoods and reduce environmental pressures to the TSBR, the project will undertake a series of interventions aimed at creating sustainable livelihood and employment opportunities in eco-tourism, solar energy, and sustainable agriculture, fish processing and forestry.
Culture and Environment Preservation Association (CEPA) creates an enabling ecosystem for a sustainable and functional eco-tourism industry in the Tonle Sap Biosphere Reserve (TSBR ) that will support both community-based eco-tourism entrepreneurship and boost investment from the hospitality sector to generate employment opportunities. CEPA provides training to foster skill development for community-based eco-tourism, includinghome stay management and tour guide development. In addition, CEPA provides training on fish processing, horticulture, Non Timber Forest Products (NTFPs ) to the community. The project providesbasic facilities/equipment such as camping tents, paddles ,wooden boats, and Kayaks as part of practical exercises, to be transferred to the community at the end of the project

participating-org.narrative: The Rivers Coalition in Cambodia (RCC) has been progressing since its early formation in 2007 to support farmers and fishers groups, in particular the dam-affected communities, to influence government policies related to water governance of the Mekong byupholdingcommunities’ rights to be consulted on various development initiatives affecting their food security and livelihoods. RCC is a loose network of 28 organizations, consisting of both national and international NGOs, and 12 regional partners. In order to become moreeffective in representing their constituency, the Action will accommodate RCC to define its future strategies and plans by seeking strategic complementarities (clarities on roles and responsibilities) among all RCC’s members. The network is led by its members, while the NGO Forum on Cambodia, a broad advocacy network of more than 80 NGOs in Cambodia, is acting as its secretariat. Funding for the main activities of the RCC is therefore already funded through the NGO-Forum. In view of this project CEPA was selected to be the main actor in this proposal as a key member of the RCC. This is in the understanding that support to an active member of the RCC and with close focus on support to networking activities also the RCC would be strengthened. Additionally CEPA (like other active members as 3SPN, and FACT) is working closely with a range of groups of farmers and fishers, who are target groups for the Action, along the Mekong, Sesan, Srepok and Sekong Rivers as well as the Tonle Sap area.The Action will provide assistance to all members of RCC via CEPA and at the same time strengthen the network to become more effective in organising the fishers and farmers groups.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood
